results.title: City port
results.creator_credit: Roger Dunton, David Powell and Abacus Documentaries
results.brief_description: Shows how the City of London, Lloyd’s, the Bank of England and other commercial institutions support the Port of London, and how the Port supplies goods to the city.

results.title: City of gold
results.creator_credit: Colin Low, Wolf Koenig, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A nostalgic recollection of the period when the Yukon gold fever was at its height. The commentary, written and spoken by Dawson-born Pierre Berton, begins with childhood recollections of the writer. This feeling of retrospect is further deepened by the introduction of many vintage photographs which give the film a documentary quality as it reviews the history of the gold rush. We see relics of the old Dawson as it was when all the gold of the rich river beds flowed through its stores, taverns and dance halls.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Low, Wolf Koenig, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: City of Geelong
results.creator_credit: Bern Gandy, John Heyer and Shell Company of Australia
results.brief_description: One hundred years ago, Geelong was aboriginal country. Today, from a town which was built on wool and wheat, it has grown to be one of the biggest regional cities in Australia. Besides serving as the natural port for the produce from the rich hinterland farms, it has developed many secondary industries which make it the most industrialised city per head in Australia. Fine modern buildings, famous schools, and beautiful beaches show it as an attractive and happy city. Nestled around Corio Bay, it is prosperous and expanding.

results.title: City life
results.brief_description: A light-hearted sketch of life in the city of Sydney. The hazards of driving and parking a car in the city area and the people in Hyde Park are seen against a background of light music. No narration.

results.title: A City in the country: Albury Wodonga development
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Anthony Buckley and Film Australia
results.brief_description: With forty-two percent of the Australia’s population in Sydney and Melbourne, there is a need for decentralization. Because of this, the government has acted to create a new growth area near the border of Victoria and New South Wales. This film studies the many factors involved in planning a new community.

results.title: City in siege
results.creator_credit: Allen Stark, James Parker, Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A record of Winnipeg’s ordeal by flood in the spring of 1950. From the first overflowing drain to the broad sea that the Red River finally became, the film traces the course of this disaster. Scenes of wholesale destruction are matched by pictures of heroic rescue and defence work. When the waters recede we enter sodden houses to find mouldy walls, slimy floors and rotting furniture. But the film does not end on a note of despair - our last view of the flood area shows the work of reconstruction beginning with the removal of dykes and the restoration of roads. Voice and narration by Jack Scott. Photography by Robert Campbell and Hector Lemieux.

results.title: The City changes
results.creator_credit: Andrew Janczak and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: As people’s needs change, cities must grow and change to meet these needs. Some changes are obvious; others are subtle. How do they affect people? Can all changes be considered improvements? Designed with minimum narration - and open-ended - allows students to observe and analyze reasons for change and to determine the degree to which the community can or should exercise control over change.

results.title: A City called Copenhagen
results.creator_credit: Jorgen Roos, Danish Government Film Office and Minerva Films
results.brief_description: An informal portrait of Copenhagen, emphasising the poetry and picturesqueness of everyday life. Among the delightful scenes and pictures are municipal dances in the park, the Tivoli Gardens, the old people’s town, children at the pantomime, fishermen and an artist at the docks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jorgen Roos, Danish Government Film Office and Minerva Films

results.title: City bound
results.creator_credit: Robin Carruthers, Ivan Scott, Denning Films and Spectator Productions
results.brief_description: A study of London’s transport system during World War II. Between 5.30am and 10.00am each morning London’s underground and above-ground transport fleet carried nearly five million workers to city offices, shops, factories, and dockyards; many of these people lived in the most distant residential outer suburbs of London, and were brought in to the city every day from distances of up to 30 miles or more away. “City bound” shows us the daily migration by train, tram, bus, and tube.

results.title: The City and the self
results.brief_description: Presents a study of human relations in the city based on psychological concepts formulated by Professor Stanley Milgram. Examines the city dwellers’ perception of their city and their behavior in created situations.
